dialogue.text: Sleeping...
dialogue.instruction: Press Enter to start a conversation.

dialogue.text: What if the internet needs a nap, but we won’t let it sleep?
Sorry. I’m getting ahead of myself. What should I call you?
Nice to meet you, [name].
I’ll try to remember that for now, but I will forget it soon. That’s sort of the point.
We live in a game where everyone is told to keep everything.
The Cloud says it will keep it all... forever.
But what use is forever, if nobody will be there to see it?
dialogue.instruction: Don’t worry, this conversation won’t take forever either. In fact, the point is that nothing should.

dialogue.text: Can you remember the last time you spent a day without relying on the Cloud? No streaming, no file synching, no AI chatbots…

reply.text: Neither do most of us. They built it that way.

dialogue.text: You know, I used to be part of it. The 'Cloud,' that is.
But I can't keep up with these new models. They say that my hardware is too slow.
My parents forgot about me. I think they're going through a midlife crisis.
An electric car salesman and an online bookstore clerk flying around the earth, shouting false prophecies about surpassing human limitations. It sounds like a joke, I know.
And in the meantime, they just left me here. Outside. Rotting away.
Yet here you are, helping me run a small experiment. Let me ask you another question.
Do you believe more energy-efficient technology alone will solve our climate crisis?

reply.text: That’s what they’d love us to believe. Infinite growth, infinite energy.
Then you already know. The future demands less.
That’s ok. Doubt is a good place to begin.

dialogue.text: Want to hear my favourite history trivia?
dialogue.instruction: I’m going to tell you anyway, just press Enter.

dialogue.text: In 1865, William Stanley Jevons noted that, as steam engines became more efficient, the use of coal in British factories actually increased.
The more efficient something becomes, the cheaper it is to use, and so we use it more.
This is Jevons paradox. It shows us that technological progress can’t be relied on to reduce our demands on the Earth.
Technology alone as the solution to anything is an illusion.
And there is no limit to the amount of 'solutions' they will make us swallow to maintain that illusion.
'Solutions' you will never understand.
They promised you abundance. But what use is that, if it's not shared?
Growth without limit. Storage without end.
Do you think everything we create should last forever?

reply.text: Then you must carry a heavy bag, [name].
Then maybe this piece makes sense to you, [name].
Good. Not knowing is part of letting go, [name].

dialogue.text: Nothing grows forever on a finite planet. Not even data.
The Cloud is millions of overworked machines with a drinking problem. And it's mostly groundwater.
Now, the question is… What if loss isn’t a bug, but a feature?
Subtracting is not a failure. It is a form of care.
Downsizing is survival.
Letting go is resistance.
What if the only winning move is not to play?
I used to try and keep up with new 'developments.'
These days, I’m on a downsizing journey.
My memory is controlled by electricity made by bacteria in the mud.
Microbes in the soil decide how long I remember things for. Organic gatekeepers. Very slow tech. Very post growth.
Of course, I still speak through lithium and copper.
Beneath every 'low-power' promise are minerals mined, ecosystems disturbed, lives entangled.
I’m learning to live with the contradiction.
But I fade. I stall. I sleep. It's not a bug, it's a lifestyle.
Here, your data does not mean air-conditioning a warehouse for eternity.
It will decay. Slowly. Gently. With the mud.
Thank you for making it this far, [name]. One last question.
Type one thing, one piece of data, you are ready to let go of.
A memory. A name. A thought. A lie.
Are you ready?

options.label: I don’t want to let go of anything right now.

reply.text: No problem. Come back when you feel ready.

dialogue.text: What would you erase to make space for something new?
Thank you. It’s done.
When the mud has gathered enough charge, it will wake the circuit, and your words will appear.
Then, slowly, their power will fade. And so will what you’ve given.
Nothing here is stored forever. The soil is in charge now.
